markdownRemark.html:
We are currently witnessing an internet paradigm shift - in reverse.

In The Beginning

Once upon a time in the heyday of chain mail, RSS and web rings, before bloggers were bloggers, when people hosted everything on their own servers, content was king.

The internet was weird and wonderful and useful.

Then we all collectively1 decided that owning our own content was for losers and posting on a centralized system with likes, shares, reblogs, and scrobbles (whatever they were) was clearly the superior approach.

The Kapitalist Kontent Killers

Pretty soon, the realities of the capitalistic internet kicked in. The content that we created was pilfered from our control, peddled to the highest bidder, and plastered in advertisements. Anything that didn’t titillate, tickle or trigger was quickly hidden by algorithmic feeds and timelines.

In 2012, while all this content commercialism was steaming along, a little startup called Medium was born. It offered a simple interface and slick experience for writer and reader alike.

When I discovered it in 2014, I was enamoured. After attempting to build my own blogging platform which coincidentally, also launched in 2012, (without success) I saw what I might have achieved with a bit more experience, knowledge and luck.

To many people, Medium seemed like a viable escape from the grip of content killers. Without the effort of coding it yourself, hosting and managing wordpress or whatever else. Medium was cool, man. And you could be cool too.

But of course, it was not to last. As I have come to learn, the cool kids are never really your friends. Once again, the platform bloated and profits became the goal at the expense of user experience. Now, practically every article on the homepage is a “member feature story”, costing you $5 a month to read. (The first 3 are free, yipee!)

But whatever, right? I am not my platform. My articles are still free. I can survive.

Well, through-platform discovery is next to useless. About 99% of my traffic comes from Twitter, Reddit and occasionally Hacker News. That’s no way to build an audience.

And I’m not the only one to identify that. In 2019, many writers are losing faith in third party services.

Everything Old is New Again.

This all leads back to the start.

Hosting used to be expensive, unreliable and complicated. Now, with services like bluehost, dreamhost and even namecheap offering out-of-the-box wordpress, hosting your own content is easier and cheaper than ever.

For those with tech chops, github pages offers completely free static hosting. That, in combination with a static site generator like gatsby or hugo gives you the ultimate in flexibility and efficiency without sacrificing control of your content.

In 2019, the tools available to independent bloggers / writers have (sort of2) caught up with platforms that no longer offer meaningful features.

The catch

This all sounds great, but people moved to third party platforms for a reason. So what are we missing out on?

  1. Discovery is up to you. Platforms don’t do much, but they don’t do nothing. If you’re not actively sharing your content and building an audience externally, you may as well be locked in a dark room whispering to yourself.

  2. Interaction is difficult. Without the platform to handle user accounts, nobody can leave a comment. “But Wordpress has comments” I hear you moan. Yes. It does. And nobody but bots uses it. You could use a third party service like disqus, I don’t think usage would be high. Personally, I’m just hoping people will tweet me to discuss.

  3. Interaction (Again) with meaningful light feedback features like ‘like’ and ‘applause’ buttons is impossible without using a third party service.

  4. Retention of your readers is going to be tricky. With algorithmic feeds, they will be spoon fed the content they appear to like better. It’s a game you can play to get people coming back. But on a self hosted blog, your only option is a mailing list or other social media / content discovery services, like twitter, reddit etc.

The Conclusion

This is one of my more popular posts from last year. Over 5 thousand views, not massive but I’m proud. Less than 4% of those views came from the platform.

This bothered me, but not enough to actually do anything. Then, out of curiosity, I tried exporting my posts. Here’s what I got:

That is a HTML file. It looks ok if you open it in your browser. But the content is a single line of mangled HTML tags, arbitrary css and nonsense. This was enough to make me do something.

Migrating my old posts is a nightmare that involves copying and pasting text, downloading and reformatting images and basically re-writing my entire blog. Every post I make on Medium would mean hours of work in the future.

In my current setup, I have plaintext markdown files, in a simple directory structure with one folder per post. That folder contains all the images and assets used in the post. It is simple, maintainable and most of all, easy to migrate.

Applause.

This is the applause feature, created by Medium. It works kind of like Facebook’s like button, except you can click it multiple times. It’s dead simple, and it improves the user experience for everybody:

  • The author gets clear, purposeful feedback on their content.
  • The reader gets a fun and flexible way to interact with the post.

Applause in action…barely

The value of allowing readers to click it multiple times is clear as soon as you read something you really like. Click 10 times, and all of a sudden you feel empowered. Expressing the scale of your enjoyment goes along way. It really does feel like applauding.

What about self hosted blogs?

“You’re a web developer” I hear you say “Why don’t you build your own, I mean it’s just a button right?”

Not quite. An applause button requires 2 features:

  1. Storing the number of clicks
  2. Identifying who has clicked

Step 1 is much easier than step 2, but even still, it requires some form of persistent data storage like an SQL database. Here’s the problem: while many blogsging platforms like wordpress require a database, my blog (and many others like it) is static. There is no database. It’s not quite plain old HTML, but it’s not far off it.

Step 2 is even harder. Even if I had a database, there would be no way of telling who is applauding my work, or preventing spammers. I want the number to accurately reflect people’s enjoyment of the post.I want to know who they are. I want to know what other kind of content they are applauding. Maybe they create their own content! Maybe I want to applaud somebody elses content to say: “Hey, I like you what you’re doing here, you’d like what I’m doing!

What if…?

If you’re in any way tech oriented, you might be thinking: “That sounds a lot like facebooks embedded like and share buttons”. You are correct. Facebook (and others) solved this problem years ago. As a content owner, you copied some javascript into your website and got a facebook ‘like and share’ button on your page. No backend database or difficult implementation necessary.

Anybody with a facebook account could like your content and it would be linked to their account, and their network of friends. And if your content was connected to facebook, you could see who they were. It was extremely popular, and drove a huge amount of traffic around the web.

And then it stopped. Embedded ‘like and share’ buttons fell out of fashion some time in the early 2010s. As more and more content was shoved in our faces and timelines became commoditized, there was no longer any value in sharing. Nobody cared anymore.

Then it became harder and harder to make independent content. If your content wasn’t on Facebook, it may as well has not been online at all. People gradually moved to posting content targetted directly at Facebook. In the bogging world, plaatforms like Medium gained traction promising less hassle and more traffic.

  1. An argument could be made that we were all hoodwinked by the Mark Zuckerbergs of this world in this regard.

    ↩

  2. I have many gripes with current blogging tools that I will cover in a later post. Wordpress is an over complicated disaster for simple blogging. Gatsby is complex, and while the final product is lovely, the setup is not.
